hints.content:
Every coin has a different value.

Coin name | Picture | Value
- | - | -
Penny | ![](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/d0799f515398b1f48cb0baa7bdc8d0c12e26c70c.png) | $1¢$
Nickel | ![](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/f6c7ae82228012be92b624995809aeabc8e95370.png) | $5¢$
Dime | ![](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/2017369b968caa0c88d046bddf2406665c8cd34d.png) | $10¢$
Quarter | ![](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/1cc5cb6f4c779c49984f5a63a58443ce0ca96ff9.png) | $25¢$

Let's label the value of each set of coins and find the total.

###$6$ nickels and $4$ pennies

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢} +\goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢}}_{\goldE{6}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢} +\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\goldE{30¢}}_{\goldE{6}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{4¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}=34¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $34¢$, so it is **not** equal to $64¢$.

###$2$ quarters, $2$ dimes, and $4$ pennies

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢} +\blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{2}{\text{ quarters}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{10¢} + \purpleD{10¢}}_{\purpleD{2}{\text{ dimes}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}+\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\blueE{50¢}}_{\blueE{2}{\text{ quarters}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{20¢}}_{\purpleD{2}{\text{ dimes}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{4¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}=74¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $74¢$, so it is **not** equal to $64¢$.

###$2$ quarters, $2$ nickels, and $4$ pennies

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢} +\blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{2}{\text{ quarters}}}+ \underbrace{\goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢}}_{\goldE{2}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}+\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\blueE{50¢}}_{\blueE{2}{\text{ quarters}}}  + \underbrace{\goldE{10¢}}_{\goldE{2}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{4¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}=64¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $64¢$, so it **is** equal to Kylan's amount of money.

Kylan could have this set of coins:

$2$ quarters, $2$ nickels, and $4$ pennies

question.content:
Kylan has $64¢$.

**Which set of coins could Kylan have?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
